```{r setup, include=FALSE}
library(projoint)
```

## 🎯 Estimate Corrected MMs or AMCEs

In conjoint analysis, default MMs and AMCEs can be **biased** due to measurement error from intra-respondent variability.

**projoint** corrects for this bias automatically.

---

## 📦 Load Data Example

```{r}
outcomes <- paste0("choice", 1:8)
outcomes <- c(outcomes, "choice1_repeated_flipped")
out1 <- reshape_projoint(exampleData1, outcomes)
```

---

## 🛠️ Why Use IDs (e.g., `att1`, `level1`)?

We recommend working with **attribute IDs** rather than actual text labels because:

- Safer against special characters, languages, or typos
- Allows **multiple attributes** to have identical labels (e.g., "High" for both "Teaching Quality" and "Research Quality")

Check attribute-level mappings:

```{r}
out1$labels
```

You can also save these labels for easier editing:

```r
save_labels(out1, "labels.csv")
```

---

## 📈 Estimate Marginal Means (MMs)

<details><summary><b>Estimate Profile-Level MMs (All Levels)</b></summary>

```{r}
mm0 <- projoint(out1, .structure = "profile_level", .estimand = "mm")
print(mm0)
summary(mm0)
```

</details>

<details><summary><b>Estimate Profile-Level MMs (Specific Level)</b></summary>

```{r}
qoi_1 <- set_qoi(
  .structure = "profile_level",
  .estimand = "mm",
  .att_choose = "att1",
  .lev_choose = "level1"
)

mm1 <- projoint(out1, .qoi = qoi_1)
print(mm1)
summary(mm1)
```

</details>

<details><summary><b>Estimate Profile-Level MMs (Specific Level, Manual IRR)</b></summary>

```{r}
mm1b <- projoint(out1, .qoi = qoi_1, .irr = 0.75)
print(mm1b)
summary(mm1b)
```

</details>

<details><summary><b>Estimate Choice-Level MMs (Specific Level)</b></summary>

```{r}
qoi_2 <- set_qoi(
  .structure = "choice_level",
  .att_choose = "att1",
  .lev_choose = "level3",
  .att_notchoose = "att1",
  .lev_notchoose = "level1"
)

mm2 <- projoint(out1, .qoi = qoi_2, .ignore_position = FALSE)
print(mm2)
summary(mm2)
```

</details>

---

## 📉 Estimate AMCEs

<details><summary><b>Estimate Profile-Level AMCEs (All Levels)</b></summary>

```{r}
amce0 <- projoint(out1, .structure = "profile_level", .estimand = "amce")
print(amce0)
summary(amce0)
```

</details>

<details><summary><b>Estimate Profile-Level AMCEs (Specific Level)</b></summary>

```{r}
qoi_3 <- set_qoi(
  .structure = "profile_level",
  .estimand = "amce",
  .att_choose = "att1",
  .lev_choose = "level3",
  .att_choose_b = "att1",
  .lev_choose_b = "level1"
)

amce1 <- projoint(out1, .qoi = qoi_3)
print(amce1)
summary(amce1)
```

</details>

<details><summary><b>Estimate Profile-Level AMCEs (Specific Level, Manual IRR)</b></summary>

```{r}
amce1b <- projoint(out1, .qoi = qoi_3, .irr = 0.75)
print(amce1b)
summary(amce1b)
```

</details>

<details><summary><b>Estimate Choice-Level AMCEs (Specific Level)</b></summary>

```{r}
qoi_4 <- set_qoi(
  .structure = "choice_level",
  .estimand = "amce",
  .att_choose = "att1",
  .lev_choose = "level3",
  .att_notchoose = "att1",
  .lev_notchoose = "level1",
  .att_choose_b = "att1",
  .lev_choose_b = "level2",
  .att_notchoose_b = "att1",
  .lev_notchoose_b = "level1"
)

amce2 <- projoint(out1, .qoi = qoi_4, .ignore_position = TRUE)
print(amce2)
summary(amce2)
```

</details>

---

## 🔎 Predict Intra-Respondent Reliability (IRR)

If your design does **not** include a repeated task, you can estimate IRR using extrapolation.

<details><summary><b>Predict IRR Using `predict_tau()`</b></summary>

```{r}
data(out1_arranged)
predicted_irr <- predict_tau(out1_arranged)

print(predicted_irr)
summary(predicted_irr)
plot(predicted_irr)
```

</details>

---

## 🌟 Key Tip

Use `.by_var` **only** when comparing **profile-level MMs** between two groups (e.g., Democrats vs. Republicans).
